tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the ratio of fundamental frequencies, which involves understanding torsional vibration and boundary conditions. It requires knowledge of the natural frequencies for both fixed-free and fixed-fixed configurations and then calculating the ratio, making it a multi-step numerical calculation with some conceptual understanding.

answer_validation.reasoning: For torsional vibration of a uniform rod, the governing equation is the same as for longitudinal vibration of a bar or torsional wave in a shaft. The natural frequencies depend on the boundary conditions through the eigenvalues. For a fixed-free rod in torsion, the fundamental mode corresponds to a quarter-wave: the length L equals one-quarter of the torsional wavelength, so the fundamental circular frequency is $\omega_{1,\text{FF}} = \dfrac{\pi C}{2L}$, where $C = \sqrt{G/\rho}$ is the torsional wave speed. For a fixed-fixed rod, both ends are nodes of rotation, so the fundamental corresponds to a half-wave over the length: $\omega_{1,\text{FFx}} = \dfrac{\pi C}{L}$. The ratio is $k = \dfrac{\omega_{1,\text{fixed-fixed}}}{\omega_{1,\text{fixed-free}}} = \dfrac{\pi C/L}{\pi C/(2L)} = 2$. Thus k = 2.0, which matches option C and the official key.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recall that torsional vibration of a uniform rod is governed by a wave equation whose natural frequencies depend on boundary conditions via eigenvalues.
Step 2: For a fixed-free rod in torsion, the fundamental mode is a quarter-wave along the length, giving $\omega_{1,\text{fixed-free}} = \dfrac{\pi C}{2L}$, where $C = \sqrt{G/\rho}$.
Step 3: For a fixed-fixed rod, both ends are fixed (zero rotation), so the fundamental mode is a half-wave along the length, giving $\omega_{1,\text{fixed-fixed}} = \dfrac{\pi C}{L}$.
Step 4: Take the ratio $k = \dfrac{\omega_{1,\text{fixed-fixed}}}{\omega_{1,\text{fixed-free}}} = \dfrac{\pi C/L}{\pi C/(2L)} = 2$.
Step 5: Conclude that $k = 2.0$, corresponding to option C.

topic.name: Vibration of continuous systems (torsional vibration of rods/shafts)
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures and Structural Dynamics -> Free and forced vibration of single and multi degree of freedom systems; Vibration of beams and shafts

concepts.name: Effect of boundary conditions on natural frequencies
Wave equation eigenvalues for fixed-fixed and fixed-free conditions

essential: Basic understanding of natural frequencies and mode shapes
Torsional vibration of a uniform shaft/rod
Role of boundary conditions (fixed, free) in vibration problems
Wave interpretation of modes (quarter-wave, half-wave, full-wave)
helpful: Analogy between torsional vibration of rods and longitudinal vibration of bars
Familiarity with solving simple Sturm-Liouville eigenvalue problems

Main Concept: requires: Torsional vibration of a uniform rod and its governing equation
requires: Understanding of boundary conditions (fixed vs free) in continuous systems
enables: Ability to quickly compare natural frequencies for different end conditions
enables: Design and tuning of shafts to avoid resonance by modifying supports

difficulty_factors: Requires remembering or quickly reconstructing eigenvalue patterns for different boundary conditions
Students may confuse torsional case with bending beam frequency ratios

textbook_references.author: T. H. G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: The mode shapes for a fixed-fixed rod are sinusoidal, with nodes at the fixed ends. The natural frequencies are $\omega_n = (n \pi / L) \sqrt{G / \rho}$.

video_references.professor: Prof. S. K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.book_reference: Megson, Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Torsional vibration of fixed-fixed rods: equation of motion, boundary conditions, natural frequencies and mode shapes

video_references.professor: Prof. S. K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Torsional vibration of a fixed-free rod with attached inertia and boundary conditions

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Recall eigenvalue patterns for torsional rod with different boundary conditions \u2192 Write fundamental frequency expressions \u2192 Take ratio \u2192 Simplify \u2192 Match option
key_insights: Fundamental torsional mode for fixed-free is a quarter-wave, for fixed-fixed is a half-wave.
The wave speed and material properties cancel in the ratio; only the geometric factor (half vs quarter wave) matters.

formulas_principles.name: Torsional wave equation for a uniform rod
formulas_principles.conditions: Uniform rod, linear elastic torsion, small deformations
formulas_principles.relevance: Governing equation whose eigenvalues give natural frequencies; same form as in RAG chunk 1.

formulas_principles.name: Torsional wave speed
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates material properties to wave speed; appears in frequency expressions but cancels in the ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Natural frequencies for fixed-fixed torsional rod
formulas_principles.conditions: Both ends fixed (zero rotation), integer mode number n
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to get fundamental frequency for fixed-fixed case (n = 1).

formulas_principles.name: Fundamental frequency for fixed-free torsional rod
formulas_principles.conditions: One end fixed, other end free (zero torque), first mode
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to get fundamental frequency for fixed-free case; quarter-wave condition.

industry_examples: Drive shafts in helicopters or turboprop aircraft, where changing support conditions (adding a bearing or coupling) alters torsional natural frequencies.
Gas turbine engine accessory gearboxes and shafts, where boundary conditions at gear and disc interfaces affect torsional resonance.
specific_systems: Helicopter tail rotor drive shaft supported by multiple bearings (effectively closer to fixed-fixed segments).
Propeller shaft of a turboprop aircraft between gearbox and propeller hub.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Knowing how boundary conditions change natural frequencies helps engineers avoid torsional resonance by modifying supports or constraints, which is critical for fatigue life and noise/vibration control in rotating machinery.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that changing from fixed-free to fixed-fixed doubles the mode number n directly without checking the eigenvalue pattern, or thinking the ratio is π because π appears in the formulas.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students often remember only that π appears in frequency expressions and guess ratios like π, or confuse with other beam problems.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Visualize the mode shapes as standing waves: fixed-free is a quarter-wave for the fundamental, fixed-fixed is a half-wave. A half-wave is twice as long as a quarter-wave, so the frequency is twice.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing wrong options like π or 1.5 instead of the correct factor 2.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mixing up torsional vibration with bending vibration of beams and using bending frequency ratios or formulas.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Both topics involve rods and boundary conditions, so students may recall the wrong set of formulas.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Note that torsional and longitudinal problems usually have simple sine/cosine eigenvalues (nπ/L), while Euler-Bernoulli bending beams involve more complex transcendental equations and different eigenvalues.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect ratio and misunderstanding of how boundary conditions affect torsional modes.

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to derive the full solution from the PDE under exam pressure instead of using known standard results for eigenvalues.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Lack of confidence in memorized results or not recognizing it as a standard configuration.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Before the exam, memorize the basic eigenvalue patterns for rods: fixed-fixed, fixed-free, free-free. In the exam, directly use these instead of re-deriving.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and increases chance of algebraic mistakes.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Quarter vs Half: Fixed-Free is a Quarter, Fixed-Fixed is Half
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Fundamental mode shape length for different boundary conditions (torsion/longitudinal rods)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when comparing fundamental frequencies for fixed-free and fixed-fixed rods.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Adding constraints (from free to fixed) generally increases stiffness and hence natural frequency
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use to remember that fixed-fixed has higher frequency than fixed-free.

flashcards.front: Write the expression for natural frequencies of a uniform torsional rod with fixed-fixed ends.
For a torsional rod, what is the fundamental mode shape length for fixed-free vs fixed-fixed boundary conditions?
flashcards.back: Fixed-free: quarter-wave along the rod (node at fixed end, antinode at free end). Fixed-fixed: half-wave along the rod (nodes at both ends).

flashcards.front: A rod in torsion changes from fixed-free to fixed-fixed. By what factor does the fundamental natural frequency change?
flashcards.back: It doubles: $k = 2.0$, because fixed-free fundamental is a quarter-wave ($\omega_1 = \pi C / (2L)$) and fixed-fixed is a half-wave ($\omega_1 = \pi C / L$).

flashcards.front: Why is the ratio of fundamental torsional frequencies (fixed-fixed / fixed-free) not equal to $\pi$?
flashcards.back: Both frequencies contain $\pi$ and the same wave speed $C$, which cancel in the ratio. Only the geometric factors (half-wave vs quarter-wave) remain, giving a ratio of 2, not $\pi$.

real_world_context.application: Design of rotating shafts in aero-engines and rotorcraft drive systems
real_world_context.industry_example: In a helicopter tail rotor drive shaft, adding an extra bearing (changing effective boundary conditions from closer to fixed-free to closer to fixed-fixed between supports) increases torsional natural frequencies, helping avoid resonance with engine orders.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of torsional frequencies can lead to resonance, causing high vibration, noise, and potential fatigue failure of shafts or couplings.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize this as a standard frequency-ratio question. Recall quarter-wave vs half-wave for rods and quickly compute the ratio (2). It should take under 1–2 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that adding a fixed support increases stiffness and thus frequency, so k must be greater than 1. Eliminate 0.5. Ratios like π are unlikely; 2.0 is the most reasonable.
exam_strategy.time_management: Do this question early as a quick score; avoid over-deriving the PDE solution. If you cannot recall formulas within 60–90 seconds, make an educated guess and move on.

search_keywords: torsional vibration fixed fixed rod natural frequencies
torsional vibration fixed free shaft fundamental mode
wave equation torsional rod boundary conditions
GATE AE torsional vibration frequency ratio
standing waves in rods quarter wave half wave
S S Rao torsional vibration of shafts

alternative_methods.name: Full eigenvalue derivation from torsional wave equation
alternative_methods.description: Start from the torsional wave equation $\partial^2 \theta / \partial t^2 = C^2 \partial^2 \theta / \partial x^2$. Assume $\theta(x,t) = \phi(x) q(t)$, separate variables to get spatial ODE $\phi'' + (\omega^2/C^2) \phi = 0$. Apply boundary conditions for fixed-free and fixed-fixed to obtain allowed values of $\omega$ and then take the ratio.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reinforces understanding of PDEs, separation of variables, and boundary conditions. Cons: Time-consuming and unnecessary for a 1-mark GATE question.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Use while studying at home to deeply understand where the standard formulas come from, not during the exam.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mathematics: Eigenvalue problems and Sturm-Liouville theory underpin the derivation of mode shapes and natural frequencies for continuous systems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Vibrations: Concepts of natural frequencies, mode shapes, and boundary conditions are shared with lumped-parameter MDOF systems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: Torsion of circular shafts (G, polar moment of inertia, angle of twist) provides the physical basis for torsional stiffness and wave speed.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of torsional wave equation using Hamilton's principle
Comparison of torsional, longitudinal, and bending vibrations in rods and beams
Effect of attached end inertia (discs, flywheels) on torsional natural frequencies
Mode superposition and response of torsional shafts to harmonic excitation

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Free and forced vibration of single and multi degree of freedom systems; Vibration of beams and shafts
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely tests understanding of how boundary conditions affect natural frequencies in continuous systems without heavy computation, aligning well with the GATE AE structural dynamics syllabus.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks discussed torsional vibration of fixed-fixed rods (chunk 1) and torsional rods with different boundary conditions and attached inertia (chunk 4), as well as analogous longitudinal vibration problems (chunks 2, 3, 6). These supported recalling the general form of the torsional wave equation and eigenvalues for fixed-fixed rods. The specific fixed-free torsional eigenvalue was not explicitly given in RAG, so that part relied on internal knowledge and standard results, but the analogy with fixed-free longitudinal bars in chunk 6 helped justify the quarter-wave interpretation.

future_questions_potential: Given material properties and dimensions of a circular shaft, compute the absolute values of fundamental torsional frequencies for fixed-free and fixed-fixed conditions.
For a shaft with a disc at one end and fixed at the other, derive the transcendental frequency equation and discuss how adding another support changes the fundamental frequency.
Compare the ratios of fundamental frequencies for longitudinal and torsional vibrations of a rod when boundary conditions change from fixed-free to fixed-fixed.
Design a shaft support configuration to shift torsional natural frequencies away from a given excitation frequency range.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The boundary conditions for a rod with circular cross-section, under torsional vibration, are changed from fixed-free to fixed-fixed. The fundamental natural frequency of the fixed-fixed rod is k times that of fixed-free rod. The value of k is
